docs.lead_paragraph: No one is sure why, but researchers say it appears that women who have heart surgery are at greater risk of having strokes and other neurological problems afterward than are men who have the same operation. Writing in the American Heart Association journal Circulation, the authors speculate that the problem may lie with decreased estrogen levels. Most women who have heart surgery are beyond menopause, when levels of estrogen drop to almost nothing.

headline.main: After Heart Surgery, an Added Concern

docs.abstract: Researchers say it appears that women who have heart surgery are at greater risk of having strokes and other neurological problems afterward than are men who have same operation (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, Sal Salvaggio hid his legs. The ugly blue and red knots of veins that bulged out like clusters of grapes embarrassed him so much that he refused to wear shorts. Even more vexing was the weariness and pain he felt each evening, when he finally had a chance to rest his limbs. Mr. Salvaggio, a hair stylist in Manhattan, assumed he would just have to endure the blemishes and aches for the rest of his life. But one day, he struck up a conversation with one of his partner's customers, a well-known vein expert who had just developed a virtually painless procedure for treating varicose veins. ''I showed him my legs and he said, 'Come on over and I'll take care of them,' '' Mr. Salvaggio, 56, remembers.

headline.main: Now, Easier Ways to Eliminate Varicose Veins

docs.abstract: Easier techniques are developed to treat varicose veins, which affect 50 percent of women and 15 percent of men by age 55; one uses lasers, and the other radio waves (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study raises questions about whether the current measure used to define lead poisoning is stringent enough. Lead poisoning has been redefined over the years, as doctors have decided that smaller and smaller amounts are acceptable. It is now considered to occur at 10 micrograms of lead per deciliter of blood.

headline.main: New Warnings on Lead and Children

docs.abstract: New study raises questions about whether current measure used to define lead poisoning in children is stringent enough (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: State laws that set lower alcohol limits for teenage drivers appear to reduce the number of young people who drink and drive, researchers have found. But the study, in this month's American Journal of Public Health, also found that a lack of public awareness about the laws among both teenagers and adults were blunting their effect. Citing a 1997 Gallup survey that found that 36 percent of the driving-age public did not know about the laws, the researchers said law enforcement authorities should do more to make them known.

headline.main: A Sobering Effect on Teenage Drivers

docs.abstract: Researchers find that state laws that set lower alcohol limits for teenage drivers appear to reduce number of young people who drink and drive (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The day of the week or even the time of day a doctor examines a patient can play a significant role in making a correct diagnosis. This became clear to me when I treated a college student who came to my clinic late one Wednesday afternoon complaining of extreme fatigue. His physical and psychological examinations were unrevealing except that he was extremely pale and the color of the normally pink tissue underneath his eyelids and nails was a ghostly white.
docs.abstract: Dr Howard Market column on role of time of day, or day of week, of a medical examination in determining a diagnosis; cites case of college student whose extreme fatigue was result of bleeding ulcers in his stomach, brought on by excessive drinking (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite stringent measures to protect people and cattle from mad cow disease, experts in and out of government say more can be done. ''While the government has taken a lot of actions to prevent mad cow disease from infecting cattle, including a ban on the importation of cattle from affected countries, there are holes in the fire wall,'' said Caroline Smith DeWaal, food safety director for the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer advocacy group.

headline.main: Experts See Flaws in U.S. Mad Cow Safeguards

docs.abstract: Experts in and out of government say that despite stringent measures to protect people and cattle from mad cow disease, more can be done; their concerns center on the level of testing of cattle, the machines that strip meat scraps from carcasses, dietary supplements that may contain nervous system tissue and uneven enforcement of prion contamination of animal feed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Equipping police officers with portable defibrillators, which shock the hearts of some heart victims back into normal rhythm, could significantly increase survival rates, a new study finds. After 1,900 of the devices were given to officers in Miami-Dade County in 1999, researchers in Florida found that the survival rate there doubled.

docs.lead_paragraph: Until recently, Phil Whitton always asked to be heavily sedated before undergoing magnetic resonance imaging tests. Ms. Whitton, a nurse from Milwaukee who had a benign salivary gland tumor removed 15 years ago, still has a follow-up M.R.I. every six months. But the long, dark tunnel, the cramped quarters and the whirring racket of a standard imaging machine brought on a previously unnoticed claustrophobia so severe that she could not bear the procedure without being medicated. Now, developments in M.R.I. technology have meant that Ms. Whitton can have her procedure in an open scanner. And with new and radical improvements in open M.R.I. machines, the images of bone and tissue appear clearly and accurately, nearly matching the high-powered tunnel-type machines in diagnostic quality, but without the darkness and noise.

headline.main: Patients Embrace New Generation of Imaging Machines

docs.abstract: Developments in magnetic resonance imaging technology mean that patients can have procedure in open scanner, reducing threat of claustrophobia; open MRI machines now produce images of bone and tissue that nearly match those of high-powered tunnel-type machines in diagnostic quality, but without darkness and noise; photo (M)
